user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of ahc_main:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
ahc_main (void *cls,
          struct MHD_Connection *connection,
          const char *url,
          const char *method,
          const char *version,
          const char *upload_data, size_t *upload_data_size,
          void **req_cls)
{
  static int already_called_marker;
  size_t url_len;
  (void) cls;               /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) version;           /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) upload_data;       /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */

  if ((0 != strcmp (method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_GET))
      && (0 != strcmp (method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_HEAD)))
    return reply_with_method_not_supported (connection);

  if (0 != *upload_data_size)
    return MHD_NO; /* No upload expected for GET or HEAD */

  if (&already_called_marker != *req_cls)
  { /* Called for the first time, request not fully read yet */
    *req_cls = &already_called_marker;
    /* Wait for complete request */
    return MHD_YES;
  }

  if (0 == strcmp (url, "/"))
    return reply_with_main_page (connection);

  url_len = strlen (url);

  if ((strlen (SEC_AREA1_URL) <= url_len)
      && (0 == memcmp (url, SEC_AREA1_URL, strlen (SEC_AREA1_URL))))
    return handle_sec_areas_req (connection, url, 1); /* The requested URL is within SEC_AREA1_URL */

  if ((strlen (SEC_AREA2_URL) <= url_len)
      && (0 == memcmp (url, SEC_AREA2_URL, strlen (SEC_AREA2_URL))))
    return handle_sec_areas_req (connection, url, 2); /* The requested URL is within SEC_AREA2_URL */

  return reply_with_page_not_found (connection);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I found no uses of compiler language extensions in the provided code fragment. The function signature, use of static local variable, enum return type, void pointers, (void) casts to suppress warnings, pointer comparisons, calls to standard library functions (strlen, strcmp, memcmp) and macro-like identifiers (MHD_YES, MHD_NO, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_GET, SEC_AREA1_URL, etc.) are all standard C constructs. There are no occurrences of known compiler-specific extensions such as __attribute__, __builtin_*, typeof, statement-expressions ({: }), inline assembly (asm), zero-length arrays, named address spaces, or other vendor-specific keywords/constructs that would be explicitly documented as language extensions. If any of the referenced identifiers (types/macros) are defined in external headers using compiler-specific extensions, those definitions are outside the provided fragment and should be reviewed separately; however, nothing in the shown code itself uses an explicit compiler extension.
